G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody and parenting order of this Court concerning minor children who reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody and parenting order of this Court concerning minor children who reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a Complaint for Modification of a prior custody and parenting order of this Court concerning minor children who reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The controlling consideration in all custody and parenting matters is the best interests of the children.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that modification of custody requires a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: This case is a removal/custody allocation decision at the time of divorce, not a post‑judgment custody modification case. While it repeatedly emphasizes that the ‘best interests of the child’ are the paramount concern, it does not discuss or apply any ‘material change in circumstances’ requirement for modification. Thus it supports only the best‑interests portion of the proposition, not the full statement tying modification to a material change affecting the child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that modification of custody requires a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody case focused on the impact of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings about that issue; it does not discuss standards for *modification* of an existing custody order or articulate a ‘material change in circumstances’ requirement. While it refers generally to the best interests of the child (including the impact of family violence), it does not frame its analysis in terms of the long‑standing appellate standard for custody modification. Thus it only indirectly reflects the best‑interests principle and does not clearly support the full proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that modification of custody requires a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/joint-custody case and does not discuss the standard for modification of custody orders generally. It repeatedly applies and elaborates the ‘best interests of the child’ standard (and notes ALI language that relocation can be a substantial change in circumstances), but it does not state that a material change in circumstances is required for modification, nor does it describe that requirement as a long‑standing rule of Massachusetts appellate courts. Thus it does not affirm the full proposition claimed.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents where one of the parents seeks to relocate without the consent of the other parent. Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only ‘upon cause shown,’ meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances … .”}

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that modification of custody requires a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies and reaffirms that custody determinations turn on the best interests of the child and the child’s welfare as the paramount concern. While this case is not itself a modification proceeding, in its removal discussion it cites existing Massachusetts authority (e.g., Yannas, Custody of Kali) that requires a showing that a change (such as removal) be in the child’s best interests, reflecting the long-standing doctrinal framework that material changes affecting the child’s welfare are evaluated under the best-interests standard. Thus it supports the stated proposition about Massachusetts appellate courts’ approach to custody changes and best interests.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child.… ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402 (1981). … Ultimately, the judge must determine that removal is in the best interests of the child. Dickenson v. Cogswell, 66 Mass. App. Ct. 442, 447 (2006).”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have long held that modification of custody requires a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general best-interests-of-the-child standard for an initial custody determination, not the standard for *modification* of an existing custody order. It does not state that a material change in circumstances is required to modify custody, nor does it frame the analysis as a modification case; instead, it treats custody as an original determination incident to dissolution of the relationship. The proposition therefore overreads the case by importing the ‘material change’ requirement, which Hunter v. Rose does not address.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (463 Mass. at 494-495).

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to fashion orders to protect the best interests and welfare of minor children and to ensure that existing judgments are adapted to present conditions.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the governing standard in custody determinations (the welfare of the child) and remands for further findings; it does not invoke G.L. c. 215, § 6 or discuss the court’s broad equitable powers or modification/adaptation of existing judgments. The decision is focused narrowly on adequacy of findings and proper application of best-interests criteria, not on the scope of the Probate Court’s equitable authority to fashion or adapt orders. Accordingly, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed."

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: These comments by the Defendant disparage the Plaintiff to the children, directly contradict the 2021 Custody Order’s non-disparagement and co‑parenting provisions, and are inconsistent with the duty of each parent to foster the children’s relationship with the other parent recognized under Massachusetts law.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, joint custody, and visitation under a general ‘best interests of the child’ standard, but it does not address non‑disparagement clauses, co‑parenting provisions, or any explicit duty of each parent to foster the children’s relationship with the other parent. The references to “frequent and continuing contact” with both parents are drawn from Felton v. Felton and used only to evaluate whether joint custody is appropriate in this high‑conflict case. Rolde therefore does not provide direct authority for the specific non‑disparagement/co‑parenting duty asserted in the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 234, quoting from In re Marriage of Murga, 103 Cal. App. 3d 498, 503 (1980)…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: These comments by the Defendant disparage the Plaintiff to the children, directly contradict the 2021 Custody Order’s non-disparagement and co‑parenting provisions, and are inconsistent with the duty of each parent to foster the children’s relationship with the other parent recognized under Massachusetts law.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the statutory and common‑law ‘best interests of the child’ standard, stability, and primary‑caretaker considerations in custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C. It does not discuss non‑disparagement orders, co‑parenting provisions, or any explicit duty of each parent to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. Because the case never addresses disparaging comments to children or a legal duty not to undermine the other parent, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … [G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a)] gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’”
